Things I've written about work

Jan 31, 2023

That was January 2023

January flew, flew by, I tell you. We started with ‚Äúwow, 2023 already, let‚Äôs have a chill time this year, hey what‚Äôs on Netflix?‚Äù and at the time of writing everything is different:

  • Things are not chill, because we‚Äôre preparing ourselves, our lives, and our house for our first-ever puppy
  • Both our work lives are unexpectedly bustling and busy
  • We cancelled Netflix

I‚Äôve been saying for years that I‚Äôd be willing to pay 100 euros a month for a single, all-encompassing international streaming platform. I suppose it‚Äôs never going to happen, but, hey, at least we‚Äôll have that puppy, right?

The puppy!

Like I said, we kicked off the year very quietly, thinking ‚Äúmeh, someone asked us if we wanted a puppy, but we‚Äôre not really sure just yet.‚Äù This all changed ones we learned that eight healthy puppies were born and we were allowed to pick first. We went for a visit mid-January, and fell deeply in love with little Lemonade, who‚Äôs coming home at the end of February.

I went from a serious dog-free advocate to an expecting dog parent in two months‚Äô time, and I suppose it‚Äôs safe to say I‚Äôve gone a bit mad. I‚Äôm designing a birth announcement card, and the puppy may or may not already have a website. Help me.

Reading

I picked up a few great titles at the library this month. One that was helpful to get through was, Loose Cannons Back on Track, about managing gifted neurodivergence in the workplace. At the moment, I‚Äôm thoroughly enjoying One Continuous Mistake: Four Noble Truths for Writers by Gail Sher.

Music

Musically, the year is off to a great start. I‚Äôve made a new Brian Eno discovery that‚Äôs hard not to love, found a Mitski gem that has been on repeat, and added a great track to my work playlist: Tieduprightnow by Parcels. As always, I‚Äôve compiled a playlist of all of these and more. Feel free to check it out.

Watching

I saw Triangle of Sadness again this month, and loved it more than I did the first time. I appreciate how well this movie understands the finality of our social roles, and how, at the same time, they can be transformed in the blink of an eye. In addition, I am secretly a 13-year-old boy who likes to look at people drowning in their own vomit and excrement.

Anja and I also began watching Shrinking, which is surprisingly fun. ‚ÄòMen‚Äôs liberation movement‚Äô like Ted Lasso, but ever so slightly more depressing and realistic.

Something else

I find myself looking for great influencers focused on gifted neurodivergence. Like those many awesome YouTubers sharing tips and tricks on how to live with ADHD, but for giftedness, and not in some Mensa kind of way, but just something that‚Äôs honest about the challenges one may encounter. Most of what I find is written by pedagogues for parents of gifted children. If you know of anything, feel free to let me know.

Jan 13, 2023

`alt` text culture

More than any other time in my online life am I aware of the value of alt text. I make a point to write image descriptions whenever I can. Kind strangers with a variety of accessibility needs have been helping me understand how to best capture my interpretation of an image. I‚Äôve come to regard alt text as the secret side bar I get to have with blind people and others who need it.

For me, alt text raises interesting cultural questions, particularly around its growing visibility. Traditionally, it requires that people who don‚Äôt use accessibility tools hover an image to produce what I call ‚Äúthe world‚Äôs slowest tooltip‚Äù. In addition, I‚Äôve been seeing a growing number of people work alt text into places where it doesn‚Äôt exist. Places that don‚Äôt require a hover. Two examples of this are Mastodon‚Äôs profile and banner images.

A few weeks ago, I saw the profile picture of a young woman winking. Her bio captured the image with something along the lines of ‚Äúyoung woman looking seductively at the camera, winking, and slightly sticking out her tongue hoping to engage the viewer‚Äù. Before reading that text I felt engaged indeed, my mind painting a quick image of what her manic pixie dream girl university campus life would be like.

Reading her description of the image had an effect. I gather it was the overtness ‚Äî her self-awareness about what the image could convey ‚Äî that somehow put me off just slightly. The image and not so much her description of it but the very fact that I could even see that description, and that she understood I would, changed how I saw her in the image. It also changed how I see the Internet.

What does it mean, I‚Äôve been thinking ever since, that people with no need for alt text get to peek behind its curtain? What effect can this form of double meaning-making have? Does it mean we‚Äôll eventually go on to describe images differently, knowing that not a portion of our audience but the entirety of it is looking on? Does it mean we may, some day, try to say less with imagery? In one way, I‚Äôd consider that reduction of fluff a triumph for accessibility.

Today, Piper Haywood‚Äôs blog put me onto a handy alt text decision tree. I‚Äôm entirely surprised to read that the answer to the final question in the tree, ‚ÄúIs the image purely decorative or not intended for the user?‚Äù, is ‚Äúuse an empty alt‚Äù and not ‚Äúdon‚Äôt post the image‚Äù.

I guess that paints the best picture of how much of a reductionist I am.

Nov 1, 2020

Goodbye Airtrade, hello Leeruniek

After five years of learning, falling on my face, making friends, and getting to know the travel industry, the time has come for me to say goodbye to Airtrade. This year, the travel industry took a huge blow, with many of the small and big clients we‚Äôve acquired over the years in serious heavy water. What‚Äôs more, five years is a good run, wouldn‚Äôt you say?

My next adventure is taking me even deeper into making tools for people at work, and I couldn‚Äôt be more thrilled. I‚Äôm joining Leeruniek, a startup creating data-driven educational technology. They‚Äôre a smaller team than what I worked with the past five years, and I‚Äôm curious to see what impact that has on the way I work.

There are a lot of interesting challenges to take care of at Leeruniek, and I‚Äôm eager to get my hands dirty!
